title: Fred Weary (defensive back)
text:
Joseph Frederick Weary (born April 12, 1974) is an American former college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for six seasons during the 1990s and 2000s. Weary played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a>, was a member of a national championship team, and earned consensus <a href="All-American">All-American</a> honors. Thereafter, he played professionally for the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>, <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a> and <a href="St.%20Louis%20Rams">St. Louis Rams</a> of the NFL.
Early years.
Weary was born in <a href="Jacksonville%2C%20Florida">Jacksonville, Florida</a>. He attended <a href="Mandarin%20High%20School">Mandarin High School</a> in Jacksonville, where he played for the Mandarin Mustangs high school football team.
College career.
Weary received an athletic scholarship to attend the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a> in Gainesville, Florida, and played for coach <a href="Steve%20Spurrier">Steve Spurrier</a>'s <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida Gators football</a> team from <a href="1994%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1994</a> to <a href="1997%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1997</a>. As a junior, Weary was a starter on the Gators' <a href="1996%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1996</a> team that defeated the <a href="1996%20Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football%20team">Florida State Seminoles</a> 52–20 in the <a href="1997%20Sugar%20Bowl">1997 Sugar Bowl</a> to win the <a href="Bowl%20Alliance">Bowl Alliance</a> national championship. As a senior team captain and <a href="defensive%20back">defensive back</a> for the Gators, Weary had six <a href="interception">interception</a>s, and fifteen in his college career—the most in school history. He was a first-team All-<a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> (SEC) selection in 1996 and 1997, and a consensus first-team <a href="All-American">All-American</a> in 1997. He finished his four-year college career with fifteen interceptions and thirty-five blocked passes.
Professional career.
Weary was chosen in the fourth round (ninety-seventh pick overall) of the <a href="1998%20NFL%20Draft">1998 NFL Draft</a> by the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>, and he played for the Saints from 1998 to 2001. During his second and third seasons with the Saints, Weary became a regular starter at right cornerback; his fourth year, however, he only started in a single game.
Weary finished his NFL career with the Atlanta Falcons in and the St. Louis Rams in , seeing only limited playing time in a backup role. In his six NFL seasons, Weary appeared in eighty-three regular season games, and started twenty-five of them; he recorded 191 tackles, seven interceptions, and one interception return for a touchdown.
